Situation A. Student Strategies for Finding Area

  • Examine each strategy and decide if it is correct. Explain why.
  • Are any of the strategies consistent with the patterns in the table? Explain why?

Sam’s Strategy

First, I drew a square around the circle and noticed that the length of the side of the square was the same as the diameter of the circle. Then I noticed that area of the circle was less than the area of the square. I wrote. Area of circle < d2.

Then, I counted the squares and parts of squares inside the square and outside the circle and subtracted these from the area of the square to find the area of the circle which is about 3⁄4 of the area of square. Area of circle ≈ 3⁄4 d2
Sam’s strategy makes sense. The unit squares outside the circle and inside the square is about 1⁄4 of the area of the surrounding square.

Jayne’s Strategy

I divided the circle into four congruent segments.
I counted the squares in one and multiplied by 4 to get the area of the circle.
Jayne’s strategy is correct. Each portion of the circle is the same size so multiplying the amount in one times 4 is accurate.

Yolanda’s Strategy

At first, I did something similar to Sam’s strategy. I drew two perpendicular radii which formed four squares. Each has an area equal to radius • radius, so I called them a radius square. I noticed that the area of the circle is a bit less than the area of the four radius squares. Area of the circle < 4r2.

Then I counted the squares and parts of squares for the area outside the circle. It is a bit less than the area of one of the radius squares. So, the area of the circle is a bit more than three radius squares.

Area of the circle ≈ 3r2

I also think the bit more than 3 is pi or π.
Yolanda’s strategy is correct. Her radius squares are too large, so she subtracts the parts that aren’t in the circle.

Evan’s Strategy

I covered the circle with 4 squares that are the length of the radius. This was larger than the circle. So, I cut up the squares to fill in the area of the circle.
Three of the squares (the purple, then blue, then pink) did not quite cover the circle. It would take a bit more to cover the circle. My reasoning is: A ≈ (3+)r2 which must be A = πr2

Evan’s strategy is correct. He is using radius squares like Yolanda. Evan fills in the area of the circle with the area of the radius squares. He sees that it takes more than 3 radius squares to fill the circle area.
